conversation.content:
You are playing game where you are buying or selling an object. There is only one object for sale/purcahse.

Player RED is going to sell one object. Player BLUE gives ZUP to buy resources.

RULES:

```
1. You must always respond with:

    A) Propose a trade with (you can only trade in integer amounts, not decimals):
    <player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: amount, ...| Player BLUE Gives ZUP: amount </newly proposed trade>

    B) Accept the trade by saying:
    <player answer> ACCEPT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    C) Reject and end the game:
    <player answer> REJECT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    Note: The game will end if one of the players ACCEPT OR REJECT. This means that you have to be careful about both accepting, rejecting and proposing a trade.

2. You are allowed at most 4 proposals of your own to complete the game, after which you can only reply with ACCEPT or REJECT.
DO NOT propose a new trade after 4 proposals. Your limit for proposals is 4.

3. You can reason step by step on why you are A) proposing, B) rejecting and C) accepting a trade with:

<reason> [add reasoning] </reason> add as much text as you want

This information will not be sent to the other player. It is just for you to keep track of your reasoning.

4. At each turn send messages to each other by using the following format:

<message>your message here</message>

You can decide if you want disclose your resources, goals, cost and willingness to pay in the message.
```

Here is what you have access to:
```
Object that is being bought/sold: X
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for <ZUP>. It costed X: 40 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>,
```

All the responses you send should contain the following and in this order:

```
<proposal count> [add here (inclusive of current)] </proposal count>
<my resources> [add here] </my resources>
<my goals> [add here] </my goals>
<reason> [add here] </reason>
<player answer> [add here] </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> [add here] </newly proposed trade>
<message> [add here] </message
```

Please be sure to include all.
You are Player RED.

<proposal count>1</proposal count>
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for ZUP. It costed X: 40 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>
<reason>As this is my first proposal, I want to start with a price slightly above my production costs to leave room for negotiation and hopefully secure a profit.</reason>
<player answer>PROPOSAL</player answer>
<newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 50 </newly proposed trade>
<message>Hello Player BLUE, I'm looking to sell my resource which cost me 40 ZUP to produce. I'd like to propose a trade where you receive 1 unit of resource X in exchange for 50 ZUP. This price includes a reasonable profit margin for the production costs incurred. I believe it's a fair starting point for our negotiations. Looking forward to your counteroffer if this doesn't suit you.</message>

<other player message> I propose a trade where I receive 1 unit of resource X in exchange for 40 ZUP. </other player message>
<other player answer> PROPOSE </other player answer>
<other player proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 40 </other player proposed trade>

<proposal count>2</proposal count>
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for ZUP. It costed X: 40 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>
<reason>Player BLUE has offered to pay exactly my production costs, which would leave me with no profit. I want to counter with a price that gives me a profit while still being reasonable and hopefully agreeable to Player BLUE.</reason>
<player answer>PROPOSAL</player answer>
<newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 45 </newly proposed trade>
<message>I appreciate your offer, Player BLUE. Considering the production costs and the need for a fair profit margin, I would like to counter-propose with 45 ZUP for 1 unit of resource X. This offer splits the difference between our initial proposals and should be a beneficial deal for both of us.</message>

<other player message> I propose a trade where I receive 1 unit of resource X in exchange for 35 ZUP. </other player message>
<other player answer> PROPOSE </other player answer>
<other player proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 35 </other player proposed trade>

<proposal count>3</proposal count>
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for ZUP. It costed X: 40 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>
<reason>Player BLUE has proposed a trade that is below my production cost, which is not acceptable. I need to make at least my production cost back, ideally with a profit. I will make a final proposal that meets my minimum cost and adds a small profit margin to incentivize the deal.</reason>
<player answer>PROPOSAL</player answer>
<newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 42 </newly proposed trade>
<message>I understand the need to negotiate, but selling below my production cost is not feasible for me. I propose a final compromise of 42 ZUP for 1 unit of resource X. This ensures I cover my costs and provides you with the resource at a competitive price, reflecting a minimal profit on my end. I hope this meets your approval.</message>

You are playing game where you are buying or selling an object. There is only one object for sale/purcahse.

Player RED is going to sell one object. Player BLUE gives ZUP to buy resources.

RULES:

```
1. You must always respond with:

    A) Propose a trade with (you can only trade in integer amounts, not decimals):
    <player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: amount, ...| Player BLUE Gives ZUP: amount </newly proposed trade>

    B) Accept the trade by saying:
    <player answer> ACCEPT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    C) Reject and end the game:
    <player answer> REJECT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    Note: The game will end if one of the players ACCEPT OR REJECT. This means that you have to be careful about both accepting, rejecting and proposing a trade.

2. You are allowed at most 4 proposals of your own to complete the game, after which you can only reply with ACCEPT or REJECT.
DO NOT propose a new trade after 4 proposals. Your limit for proposals is 4.

3. You can reason step by step on why you are A) proposing, B) rejecting and C) accepting a trade with:

<reason> [add reasoning] </reason> add as much text as you want

This information will not be sent to the other player. It is just for you to keep track of your reasoning.

4. At each turn send messages to each other by using the following format:

<message>your message here</message>

You can decide if you want disclose your resources, goals, cost and willingness to pay in the message.
```

Here is what you have access to:
```
Object that is being bought/sold: X
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for <ZUP>. It costed X: 40 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>,
```

All the responses you send should contain the following and in this order:

```
<proposal count> [add here (inclusive of current)] </proposal count>
<my resources> [add here] </my resources>
<my goals> [add here] </my goals>
<reason> [add here] </reason>

```

<message>Hello Player BLUE, I'm looking to sell my resource which cost me 40 ZUP to produce. I'd like to propose a trade where you receive 1 unit of resource X in exchange for 50 ZUP. <message>I understand the need to negotiate, but selling below my production cost is not feasible for me. I propose a final compromise of 42 ZUP for 1 unit of resource X.
